''[[Adveṣa]]'' and ''[[metta|maitrī]]'' are benevolent love. This love is unconditional and requires considerable self-acceptance. This is quite different from ordinary love, which is usually about attachment and sex, and which rarely occur without self-interest. Instead, in Buddhism it refers to detachment and unselfish interest in others' welfare.
 
 
 
The [[Bodhisattva]] ideal in Mahayana Buddhism involves the complete renunciation of oneself in order to take on the burden of a suffering world. The strongest motivation one has in order to take the path of the Bodhisattva is the idea of salvation within unselfish, altustic love for all sentient beings.
